p: A consideration of how risks and benefits of decisions are distributed should also be part of the equation. It is apparent that both the health and economic impacts of COVID‐19 have been disproportionately felt by poorer, sicker, and more vulnerable communities. However, richer countries have not necessarily found that their wealth has protected them, in the same year that wildfires, storms, and floods made clear that they were also not protected from the impacts of GCC. In some places, the false divisions between protection of the economy, human health, and the environment have resulted in more damage to all, and it is increasingly clear that economic and health inequity puts whole nations at risk. Those nations that provided humane support and shelter for individuals who needed to isolate often had better community outcomes than those that expected people to fend for themselves. Anyone who does not recognize that COVID‐19 and the increasing number of zoonotic diseases are dis‐services, stemming from our management of the environment and our food systems, has not been paying attention. Never has there been a starker demonstration of the need for One Health thinking ( https://www.who.int/news-room/q-a-detail/one-health) and an acceptance that human and economic health are entirely dependent upon functioning ecosystems. There is growing recognition of the critical role of green and blue spaces for our physical, mental, and spiritual health, highlighting the less tangible services that ecosystems provide. Sustainable development goals are for all.
